title: What Is a Stock?
content:
What Is a Stock?

A stock represents partial ownership in a real company. When you buy a stock, you're purchasing a small piece of that company, which makes you a shareholder.

Think of it like a pizza cut into many slices. Each slice represents one share of stock. You might own one slice, while others own different amounts.

Key Concepts

  • Share: A single unit of ownership in a company
  • Shareholder: Anyone who owns at least one share of a company
  • Stock Market: Where stocks are bought and sold
  • Stock Price: The current value of one share, which changes based on supply and demand

Why Companies Issue Stock

Companies issue (sell) stock to raise money for:

  • Growing their business
  • Developing new products
  • Hiring more employees
  • Buying other companies
  • Paying off debts

What Shareholders Get

As a shareholder, you may receive:

  1. Potential Profits: If the company grows and becomes more valuable, your stock may increase in value
  2. Dividends: Some companies share their profits with shareholders through regular payments
  3. Voting Rights: Shareholders often get to vote on important company decisions

Real Example:

If Apple has 16 billion shares outstanding and you buy 10 shares, you own 0.0000000625% of Apple Inc. While this is a tiny percentage, you're still a real owner of the company!
